entry.shortdefinition: to accustom or become accustomed to a new climate, environment, or situation.
entry.footernotes: Acclimate is from French acclimater, from a-, "to" (from Latin ad-) + climat, "climate," from Late Latin clima, climat-, from Greek klima, "inclination; the supposed slope of the earth toward the pole; region; clime," from klinein, "to lean."

definition.data: To accustom or become accustomed to a new climate, environment, or situation.

example.quote: Getting acclimated to being in the suburbs, Sally? Mrs. Westin asked.
example.source: <cite>The Woman Who Cut Off Her Leg at the Maidstone Club and Other Stories</cite>
example.author: Julia Slavin

example.quote: The Korbels did not have much time to pull their lives together and acclimate themselves to English culture.
example.author: Ann Blackman
